channel.title: What is the auto restart plugin this server uses?
channel.description:
i must know.
minecraft servers eat memory like no tomorow and once they eat it all they tend to crash, so i need to know which plugin Moparcraft uses to restart every day at the same time.

item.title: What is the auto restart plugin this server uses?
item.dc:creator: @xx_matty_xx Justin Bieber
item.description:
@xx_matty_xx wrote:

[quote=“newbiehacker, post:21, topic:441667”][quote author=xx matty xx link=topic=544359.msg3990286#msg3990286 date=1336493673]
My guess is that it’s not a memory leak but a cache that’s not getting cleared out, like something that caches map data.
[/quote]

That would be a memory leak…

I’ve had the same problem before with a map editor I wrote. If I loaded a map it was fine, closed and opened another map and I’d get OOME. Added System.gc() to map closing function and the problem was fixed.

I think it’s bad practise to rely on an automatic function to do your memory management for you, even in the RuneScape client they call System.gc() in their custom destruction methods, and if you’re releasing/creating large amounts of data constantly you need to nudge the garbage collector occasionally (especially if you’re stealing all the CPU cycles)[/quote]Technically it’s not a memory leak if the data can still be accessed, it’s just bad memory usage. That shit about having to call gc() is dumb, if you have to do that then you’re better off using C++ or something - at least then you can manage garbage collection properly.

Read full topic
item.source: What is the auto restart plugin this server uses?

item.title: What is the auto restart plugin this server uses?
item.dc:creator: @newbiehacker newbiehacker
item.description:
@newbiehacker wrote:

xx matty xx:

My guess is that it’s not a memory leak but a cache that’s not getting cleared out, like something that caches map data.

That would be a memory leak…

I’ve had the same problem before with a map editor I wrote. If I loaded a map it was fine, closed and opened another map and I’d get OOME. Added System.gc() to map closing function and the problem was fixed.

I think it’s bad practise to rely on an automatic function to do your memory management for you, even in the RuneScape client they call System.gc() in their custom destruction methods, and if you’re releasing/creating large amounts of data constantly you need to nudge the garbage collector occasionally (especially if you’re stealing all the CPU cycles)

Read full topic
item.source: What is the auto restart plugin this server uses?

item.title: What is the auto restart plugin this server uses?
item.dc:creator: @mironic mironic
item.description:
@mironic wrote:

[quote=“Moparisthebest, post:18, topic:441667”][quote author=mironic link=topic=544359.msg3990268#msg3990268 date=1336490915]

It’s not a plugin, it’s a bash script on a cronjob. I start the server in a session of gnu screen, which I can then send commands to and such. (like quit) I tell it to stop, wait a few seconds, then kill the pid, wait a few more, then kill -9 the pid and wait a bit more, then restart it.

so its manual?
[/quote]
Of course not, I was trying to explain how the bash script worked. I can probably clean it up a little for public consumption and release it.[/quote]
we all would like that… XD

Read full topic
item.source: What is the auto restart plugin this server uses?

It’s not a plugin, it’s a bash script on a cronjob. I start the server in a session of gnu screen, which I can then send commands to and such. (like quit) I tell it to stop, wait a few seconds, then kill the pid, wait a few more, then kill -9 the pid and wait a bit more, then restart it.

so its manual?
[/quote]
Of course not, I was trying to explain how the bash script worked. I can probably clean it up a little for public consumption and release it.[/quote]

That would be nice. I would like to see how the bash script writes the server command for the count down.

It’s not a plugin, it’s a bash script on a cronjob. I start the server in a session of gnu screen, which I can then send commands to and such. (like quit) I tell it to stop, wait a few seconds, then kill the pid, wait a few more, then kill -9 the pid and wait a bit more, then restart it.
[/quote]
so its manual?[/quote]

item.source: What is the auto restart plugin this server uses?

item.title: What is the auto restart plugin this server uses?
item.dc:creator: @CoonHunter CoonHunter
item.description:
@CoonHunter wrote:

[quote=“xx matty xx, post:16, topic:441667”]Wow, that’s seriously fucked up. Even 5MB per connection with garbage collection is excessive. It does sound like your JRE is being shit though, because it should clean up automatically and you should never have to explicitly call gc unless you’re doing something really obscure.

I had to write a webserver in Java once and that could transfer a number of massive (~2GB) files simultaneously while only using ~35MB of memory. That was on OSX though, so maybe the Windows VMs are just a bit shit.[/quote]
I meant the entire server memory used stays under 4mb now, not each users used on the server was under 4mb.

Read full topic
item.source: What is the auto restart plugin this server uses?

item.title: What is the auto restart plugin this server uses?
item.dc:creator: @xx_matty_xx Justin Bieber
item.description:
@xx_matty_xx wrote:

Wow, that’s seriously fucked up. Even 5MB per connection with garbage collection is excessive. It does sound like your JRE is being shit though, because it should clean up automatically and you should never have to explicitly call gc unless you’re doing something really obscure.

I had to write a webserver in Java once and that could transfer a number of massive (~2GB) files simultaneously while only using ~35MB of memory. That was on OSX though, so maybe the Windows VMs are just a bit shit.

Read full topic
item.source: What is the auto restart plugin this server uses?

item.title: What is the auto restart plugin this server uses?
item.dc:creator: @CoonHunter CoonHunter
item.description:
@CoonHunter wrote:

[quote=“xx matty xx, post:14, topic:441667”]Doubt it - it seems to be a bit of a pointless method because the JVM should garbage collect automatically, and even a call to gc() doesn’t guarantee that the garbage is collected immediately.

My guess is that it’s not a memory leak but a cache that’s not getting cleared out, like something that caches map data.[/quote]
My chatroom’s server (currently being damn near completely-rewritten for the 4th time) would use about 5mb of memory for about 1/4 second when someone logs in. Problem was that the gc() for some reason was never running, and after a few hours of testing logging in and out (along with at one point 20 people online) it went from 3mb idle, to over 200mb of memory used. After I added a force’d gc() call every so often it now it stays under 4mb memory used even with 20-30 people online. I’m not sure if its just the jre7 version I am using, but force calling it solved all memory problems I had.

Read full topic
item.source: What is the auto restart plugin this server uses?

item.title: What is the auto restart plugin this server uses?
item.dc:creator: @xx_matty_xx Justin Bieber
item.description:
@xx_matty_xx wrote:

Doubt it - it seems to be a bit of a pointless method because the JVM should garbage collect automatically, and even a call to gc() doesn’t guarantee that the garbage is collected immediately.

My guess is that it’s not a memory leak but a cache that’s not getting cleared out, like something that caches map data.

Read full topic
item.source: What is the auto restart plugin this server uses?

item.title: What is the auto restart plugin this server uses?
item.dc:creator: @CoonHunter CoonHunter
item.description:
@CoonHunter wrote:

I always wonder if calling System.gc() (garbage collector) within a small plugin would help it save more memory.

Read full topic

Would it not be easier to just fix the underlying problem?!
[/quote] underlying problem?[/quote]When a program consumes more and more memory until it eventually crashes, there is always a problem. How do you not see this?!
